text:
> Is it possible to read a person’s mind by analyzing the electric signals from the brain?
This idea has so much purchase among some neuroscientists. I used to work at a lab doing translational research into neurodegenerative disease; the PIs thought the secrets of the brain and neurodegenerative disease were entirely encoded in the spectra of local field potential (EEG from a small section of the brain) and proselytized the works of Steriade as if they were the bible.

These people assured themselves that they could estimate the behavior of the aggregate neurons contributing to the signal to a degree which is sufficient to understand the complexities of behavior. I was never convinced.

The issues mentioned in the rest of the article linked aren't even the biggest problem with this approach to neuroscience. See: a fair portion of my colleagues weren't even aware of the Nyquist theorem.
